info.name: Water Physical Simulation
info.description: Water physics (2D wave equation) with refraction, dispersion, caustics, and specular reflections. Try drawing on the screen to make beautiful caustics (you can turn off wind/rain effects by commenting out their defs in Common).

renderpass.name: Image

renderpass.code:
//#define PAUSE_PHYSICS

//generation
#define ENABLE_RAIN
#define ENABLE_WIND

//render options
#define ENABLE_SPECULAR_REFLECTIONS
#define ENABLE_DISPERSION //chromatic dispersion for rays traveling to screen
#define ENABLE_CAUSTICS //expensive but nice-looking light patterns
#define ENABLE_CAUSTIC_DISPERSION //chromatic dispersion for caustic rays

//optimizations [4]
#define PERFORMANCE 2		//enum: 1=SPEED, 2=BALANCED, 3=QUALITY; 4=PRODUCTION; greatly affects speed
//#define CAUSTIC_CHECKERBOARD

//aesthetic constants
#define WATER_DEPTH 1.35 //screen-height multiples
#define DISPERSION .02 //[1]
//rain
#define RAIN_DROP_WEIGHT .00125
#define RAIN_DROP_SIZE 7.
#define RAIN_DROP_DELAY 10. //average delay btw rain drops
//wind
#define WIND_SPEED 10.
#define WIND_FRQ 25.
#define WIND_STRENGTH .001
//specular parameters
#define SPECULAR_LIGHT_DIR vec3(0.35, -0.3, 1)
#define SPECULAR_COLOR vec4(1,1,1,1)
//caustics parameters
#define CAUSTICS_LIGHT_DIR vec3(0.05, -.05, 1.)
#define CAUSTIC_STEP_SIZE_PX		1 //controls quality of caustics [2]
#define CAUSTIC_SEARCH_RADIUS	 	40//int(pixels) - controls range of caustics; affects speed exponentially [2]
#define CAUSTIC_PHOTON_SHARPNESS	500. //arbitrary units. should be max value that doesn't display artifacts [2]
//const vec4 CAUSTIC_BASE_COLOR = (vec4(1,1,1,1) - (vec4(1., .33, 0., 0.) * atan(WATER_DEPTH) / 1.5)) * .7; //attenuate low-frequency light
const vec4 CAUSTIC_BASE_COLOR = mix(vec4(.8, .9, 1, 1), vec4(0, .1, .6, 1), atan(WATER_DEPTH / 3.) / 1.57) * .66;
#define CAUSTIC_BRIGHTNESS			1.5

//user interface constants
#define DRAW_SIZE 50 //pixels
#define DRAW_POWER -.05//negative pulls the water, positive pushes away

//physics constants
#define VISCOSITY .996 //viscosity multiplier [3].  determines how quickly the waves lose energy.
#define REFRACTIVE_INDEX_AIR 1.000293 //actual is 1.000293
#define REFRACTIVE_INDEX_WATER 1.3330 //650nm = 1.331, 520(G) = 1.3334, 465(B) = 1.3364

//immutable constants - don't change these!
#define PI		3.1415926535979
#define TAU		6.2831853071796
#define HALF_PI 1.5707963267949
#define SQRT2	1.4142135623731
//RENDER_MODE enum
#define RENDER_DEPTH 0 //shows depth value of water surface
#define RENDER_GRADIENT 1 //shows delta-depth of water surface
#define RENDER_NORMAL 2 //shows direction of water surface curvature
#define RENDER_SPREAD 3 //shows how much each photon spread out (caustics only)
#define RENDER_CAUSTICS 4 //shows only caustics
#define RENDER_REFRACTION 5 //shows amount of light refraction
#define RENDER_TEXTURE 6 //total everything

#if PERFORMANCE == 1
	#define GRID_RATIO .33333333333 //for low-end cards
#elif PERFORMANCE == 3
	#define GRID_RATIO .75 //slow, but good quality
#elif PERFORMANCE == 4
	#define GRID_RATIO 1. //production-quality. VERY SLOW.
#else //default value = BALANCED
	#define GRID_RATIO .5 //decent quality, fast
#endif

//some functions
vec3 hsv2rgb(vec3 c) {
  vec4 K = vec4(1.0, 2.0 / 3.0, 1.0 / 3.0, 3.0);
  vec3 p = abs(fract(c.xxx + K.xyz) * 6.0 - K.www);
  return c.z * mix(K.xxx, clamp(p - K.xxx, 0.0, 1.0), c.y);
}

float lenSq(vec2 p)
{
    return dot(p,p);
}

/*
---notes---
I made it as physically accurate as possible, while taking some steps to keep the speed reasonable.
There are a lot of tunable parameters here.

[1] The "dispersion" value represents the divergence between the refractive indices at the red and blue
wavelengths, as compared to green.  Instead of calling refract() three times with different indices,
we call it once for green and then multiply the horizontal shift by the dispersion factor to get the
blue and red shifts. However this effect doesn't become apparent until the water is very deep, so the
dispersion factor was increased to amplify the effect.

[2] the CAUSTIC_SEARCH_RADIUS, along with CAUSTIC_STEP_SIZE_PX, determines the number of ray checks per pixel
and directly affects rendering speed.  The number of ray checks increases exponentially with the search radius.
The search radius should be large enough to not miss any photon contributions - how large this number needs to
be will depend on how steep the waves are and how deep the WATER_DEPTH is.  If you see excessive dark areas forming,
then you need to increase this radius.  A good stopping point is 48Â° from the target pixel, as that is the
critical angle.  The CAUSTIC_STEP_SIZE_PX is in water grid pixel units.
It is automatically adjusted by the WATER_GRID_RATIO.

Caustic photon sharpness is an arbitrary number. It should be as high as possible without causing artifacts.
There are some automatic adjustments made to it when other variables are changed.

[3] Viscosity is a multiplier representing the rate of wave energy loss due to internal friction.

[4] Optimizations: there are several optimizations available.  You may need to enable some of them
in order to go fullscreen.  Following is a list of optimizations and what they do:

PERFORMANCE: A number (1-4) indicating the speed-vs-quality factor. It defines the grid size of the water
and the caustic light patterns, as a ratio to the screen size. Grid ratios are 1/3, 1/2, 3/4, and 1, respectively.
Compute time increases with the square of the grid size, so 50% grid size is 4x faster.

CAUSTIC_CHECKERBOARD: Since ray checking is done per-pixel, we can use the checkerboard pattern with frame blending
to speed up caustic light rendering. This nearly doubles the caustic rendering speed and doesn't reduce sharpness,
however it leaves a sort of ghost pattern which may be undesirable, and at high resolutions may cause visible artifacts.

CAUSTIC_STEP_SIZE_PX: Increasing this value will increase caustic rendering speed, but will automatically reduce
photon sharpness so as not to prevent artifacts.

*/
